qas.question: How were the Roman edicts handled in some areas?
In areas of strict enforcement, what happened to Christians?
What were some provincial governors in enforcement of the Roman edicts?
When did Galerius revoke the anti-Christian policies?

context: In some cases and in some places the edicts were <a0_0>strictly enforced<a0_0/>: some Christians resisted and were <a1_0>imprisoned or martyred<a1_0/>. Others complied. Some local communities were not only pre-dominantly Christian, but <a2_0>powerful and influential<a2_0/>; and some provincial authorities were <a3_0>lenient<a3_0/>, notably the Caesar in Gaul, Constantius Chlorus, the father of Constantine I. Diocletian's successor Galerius maintained anti-Christian policy until his deathbed revocation in <a4_0>311<a4_0/>, when he asked Christians to pray for him. "This meant an ofﬁcial recognition of their importance in the religious world of the Roman empire, although one of the tetrarchs, Maximinus Daia, still oppressed Christians in his part of the empire up to 313."
